Award.AwardTitle: Center for Research on Complex Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Texas Southern University (TSU) will establish a CREST Center for Research on Complex Networks to address some of the most challenging problems of network science, network optimization and network control. The three research sub-project areas of the Center are (1) Energy Efficient Wireless Sensor Networks, which is to develop energy efficient schemes by integrating secured data aggregation and dynamic power management, investigating efficient multiple adaptation algorithms for uncertainty-aware sensor networks, and exploring dynamic control and optimization strategies; (2) Urban Transportation Environmental Networks, which is to develop and implement vehicle emission models and real-time intelligent network control methods to reduce greenhouse gas and pollutant emissions, thereby improving urban air quality; and (3) Distributed Computational Networks, which is to develop and implement algorithms for computing on networks for which the resource allocation is uneven. The research activities in the Center will involve the disciplines of computer science, mathematics, physics, chemistry, engineering technology, environmental science, and transportation. They will be strongly integrated with the science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) education programs at Texas Southern. An critical outcome of the Center will be to increase the number of under-represented minority students who pursue advanced graduate degrees, contributing to meeting the future critical workforce needs of the Nation in STEM fields.

Intellectual Merit
The intellectual merit of the Center will be the development of novel theoretical models, advanced simulation tools, and efficient physical test-beds for the study of complex networks through a multi-disciplinary approach. Moreover, the outcomes of the research will advance the knowledge of complex networks; integrate knowledge from diverse scientific areas to focus on the understanding of complex networks; and target their practical applications in real-world complex networks. The Center will have a transformative impact on TSU's effort to become one of the top research universities among Historically Black Colleges and Universities and will promote the University's collaboration with its partners from academia, industry, and government.

Broader Impacts
The broader impacts that will result from the Center's activities will be an increase of the number of under-represented minority undergraduate and graduate students, including Ph.D. students, who will be motivated to pursue cutting-edge interdisciplinary research in STEM fields. Partnerships between TSU and leading research universities in the region as well as with national laboratories will be developed. The activities in the Center will enhance the existing Ph.D. program in Environmental Toxicology in the College of Science and Technology at TSU, and will develop a new Master's degree program in the multi-disciplinary Computational Science and Engineering (CSE) at TSU. Beyond these local broader impacts, the research of the Center will provide a knowledge base for the understanding of complex networks that could allow for the development and implementation of policies for global environmental sustainability.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Texas Southern University (TSU) has been supported by NSF Center of Research Excellence in Science and Technology (NSF CREST) program to establish the Center for Research on Complex Networks (CRCN) for conducting research in complex networks through three research subprojects of energy efficient wireless sensor networks (EEWSN), urban transportation environmental networks (UTEN), and distributed computational networks (DCN). Over the project period, the project has been engaged in research on new techniques in sensor technology, pollution caused by traffic, and high-performance computing networks. It has devoted significant efforts to recruiting students and providing educational outreach. The achievement of the project has helped to enable various underrepresented minority (URM) students in pursuing advanced graduate degrees and contributing to meeting the future critical workforce needs of the nation in STEM fields. The research activities (see Fig. 1) in the three subprojects have been conducted in a parallel, but interrelated manner, involving the disciplines of computer science, mathematics, physics, chemistry, engineering technology, environmental science, and transportation.

We have developed various novel theoretical models and advanced simulation tools through over three hundred publications for the study of complex networks by a multi-disciplinary approach. The research team of the project has developed energy efficient schemes by integrating secured data aggregation and dynamic power management, by investigating efficient multiple adaptation algorithms for uncertainty-aware sensor networks, and by exploring dynamic control and optimization strategies; has made the achievement in advancing the knowledge of understandings in complex transportation and environment related science and engineering studies, proposed methodologies, frameworks, and models which have a clearly benefit for the entire society and have advanced further explorations in even advanced ecological transportation system, and life-quality oriented environmental research; and also developed algorithms to perform computations for networks that had uneven resource allocations.  

Over hundred students at TSU have been trained and supported as research assistants on this project. The significant results from the project include an increased number of minority and underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students at TSU who were motivated to pursue cutting-edge, interdisciplinary research in STEM fields, the increased visibility of TSU's NSF CREST program through various activities and significant accomplishments including, but not limited to, the following: 

(1)    Obtained one US patent; published over 100 papers in peer-reviewed journals, including publications in over 10 different IEEE Transactions, ACM Transactions, and major Transportation Journals; also, published over 200 papers in peer-reviewed conference proceedings, including those in IEEE INFOCOM, IEEE ICDCS, IEEE GLOBECOM, and international transportation conferences and other leading professional conferences; successfully organized two international conferences related to the Center's project in Houston, respectively.

(2)    Secured an additional over $7 million in research awards by the Center's faculty investigators through their work as PIs respectively; these funds came from various funding agencies, including DHS, USDOT, U.S. Army, NASA, ARO, and NSF.  

(3)    Received the first NSF Career award in TSU?s history by a Center's faculty investigator as PI; received two best research paper awards at international professional conferences; and received TSU's best awards in scholarly research/creative activities, in outstanding undergraduate academic advising, and in mentoring undergraduate research/creative activities, respectively. 

(4)    Supported and trained over 70 undergraduate students, 60 graduate students, and 7 post-doctoral fellows. 11 M.S. students were admitted to Ph.D. degree programs in other universities including the University of Florida, Virginia Tech, Texas A&M, and University of Houston, and 3 post-doctoral fellows (one from each of the three subprojects) were employed as tenure-track Assistant Professors in other U.S. universities.

(5)    Attracted over 40 middle school and high school students each summer to the Center's Enchantment Program in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). All these students were African American and Hispanic, and many of them will likely major in STEM fields. 

(6)    Permitted the CRCN to have a significant, transformative impact on the University. It has raised the visibility of research and scientific education to a prominent level. The students in the Center are beginning to see that careers in STEM are possible for them. As part of the Center's contribution to TSU, the College of Science, Engineering, and Technology (COSET) has become the largest college in the University, with an enrollment close to 2,000, which is an increase of over 30% since 2011.

(7)    Resulted in the Texas Higher Education Coordinating Board's authorization for TSU to establish two engineering programs as a large part of the Center's influence, and seven of the Center's faculty investigators were founding members of the engineering programs.
